section.title: Defining Roles and Users in the Identity Service (Keystone)
section.para: Before you begin, ensure that the OpenStack Compute and Image services are installed and connect all databases prior to configuring the Identity Service endpoints.
Next you add the default tenant, an administrator, roles, and users to get a working installation started. The initial tenant, username, and password is openstackdemo, admin, and secretword.
First, add two tenants, one named openstackdemo, one named admin.
section.literallayout: sudo keystone-manage tenant add openstackdemo sudo keystone-manage tenant add admin
section.para: In return for these commands, you should see a SUCCESS message, such as:
Now, add users and assign their passwords.
section.literallayout: sudo keystone-manage user add admin secretword sudo keystone-manage user add demo secretword
section.para: Now add an invented token (any combination of numbers and letters will do) to the admin user for the openstackdemo tenant and ensure there's an expiration date assigned. This one expires in about four years.
section.literallayout: sudo keystone-manage token add 11121314151617181920 admin openstackdemo 2015-02-05T00:0
section.para: If you see an error like "Creating a token requires a token id, user, tenant, and expiration" it's possible you're missing the expiration date.
Create the Admin role and the Member role.
section.literallayout: sudo keystone-manage role add Admin sudo keystone-manage role add Member
section.para: Grant the Admin role to the admin user and then grant the Member role to the demo user.
section.literallayout: sudo keystone-manage role grant Admin admin sudo keystone-manage role grant Member demo
section.para: Grant the Admin role to the admin user for the openstackdemo tenant.
section.literallayout: sudo keystone-manage role grant Admin admin openstackdemo

section.title: Define Services and Endpoints
section.para: Now that all your starter admin, users, and tenant have been created, let's move on to endpoints.

First add all the services you want to have the Identity service connected with. Here's an example using all the available services. sudo keystone-manage service add nova compute "Nova Compute Service" sudo keystone-manage service add glance image "Glance Image Service" sudo keystone-manage service add keystone identity "Keystone Identity Service" sudo keystone-manage service add swift object-store "Swift Object Storage Service"

Now add endpoint templates each of these now-named services, which put together the IP addresses, port values, and API version number to make an entire endpoint. sudo keystone-manage endpointTemplates add RegionOne nova http://192.168.206.130:8774/v1.1/%tenant_id% http://192.168.206.130:8774/v1.1/%tenant_id% http://192.168.206.130:8774/v1.1/%tenant_id% 1 1 sudo keystone-manage endpointTemplates add RegionOne glance http://192.168.206.130:9292/v1.1/%tenant_id% http://192.168.206.130:9292/v1.1/%tenant_id% http://192.168.206.130:9292/v1.1/%tenant_id% 1 1 sudo keystone-manage endpointTemplates add RegionOne keystone http://192.168.206.130:5000/v2.0 http://192.168.206.130:35357/v2.0 http://192.168.206.130:5000/v2.0 1 1 sudo keystone-manage endpointTemplates add RegionOne swift http://192.168.206.130:8080/v1/AUTH_%tenant_id% http://192.168.206.130:8080/ http://192.168.206.130:8080/v1/AUTH_%tenant_id% 1 1
Optionally, you can add EC2 credentials to the Identity Service for any commands you may want to use euca2ools for.
section.literallayout: sudo keystone-manage credentials add admin EC2 'admin' 'secretword' admin sudo keystone-manage credentials add demo EC2 'demo' 'secretword' openstackdemo
section.para: The Identity Service, Keystone, is now configured and ready to accept requests. Next go on to the Dashboard installation process.
